paragraphs.text: The rights of sex workers.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: In a case brought by three sex workers, the Supreme Court of Canada, in December 2013, struck down three provisions of the Canadian prostitution law
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: because they violated sex workers' human and "constitutional right to security of the person" by imposing "dangerous conditions on prostitution"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In June 2014, the Canadian government introduced a new prostitution law, Bill C-36 "Protection of Communities and Exploited Persons Act", which entered into force on December 5
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Supreme Court had created the space for a radical change in the approach to sex work by reaffirming that human and constitutional rights apply to sex workers too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: democratic procedures in Canada seem to have failed sex workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Canadian Pivot Legal Society argues that Bill C-36 has been "consistently misrepresented" and that it "will result in sweeping criminalisation of the sex industry", including sex workers themselves
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Others have called it a "hate law"
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because the safety and security of sex workers was, in fact, not the priority for some who voted for the Bill C-36
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: One of the Senators, Donald Plett, clearly stated his priority in this regard:"We don't want to make life safe for prostitutes; we want to do away with prostitution."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: Canada is not the only state that has passed questionable legislation on sex work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: ".[S]tates frequently deny sex workers the same human and legislative rights and protections afforded to other workers and citizens," says sex work researcher Jay Levy
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: The question is: How do human rights apply to sex workers and what laws and policies should states make?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: How should sex work laws look like, if human rights are to be respected to the fullest extent?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The answer to these questions is controversial - both philosophically and politically
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In the past year, numerous countries have put sex work policies on their political agenda - for different reasons and with different goals and outcomes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: There are numerous examples worldwide, where the courts have upheld sex workers' human rights and questioned existing prostitution laws or filled legal grey areas
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In New Zealand, where sex work is decriminalised, a sex worker won a case for sexual harassment against a brothel owner
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In New York, 1,900 strip club dancers won a labour rights case against their employer
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who will have to pay them at least $10m in compensation
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Recently an Austrian court has ruled that the cost of forced health checks imposed on sex workers had to be reimbursed
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Both in Germany and in Austria, court rulings abolished to notion of prostitution as being "immoral"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: thus opening up the space for legal reform and the recognition of sex work as work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The European Court of Justice has repeatedly ruled that "prostitution" is an "economic activity" and that within the European Union member states cannot restrict "freedom of movement", not even for sex workers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: court rulings are useful and necessary in reminding us that sex workers have rights too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: relying solely on courts to read human rights into existing legislation cannot be the sole answer to injustices that sex workers face
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Democracies need to step in to make laws that actually improve sex workers' lives
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: - a goal that has proven difficult to reach
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Historically marginalised and stigmatised, sex workers have a hard time in pushing for a reform of prostitution laws
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Most politicians, especially if male and heterosexual, do not wish to be associated with sex work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Prejudices and lack of knowledge about the topic as well as the unwillingness to engage with sex workers themselves have proven to be hard obstacles to surmount
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Often, sex workers are heard in consultation processes
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: their views and political claims aren't always taken seriously
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By contrast, anti-prostitution activists calling for a world without prostitution have been far more successful in their lobbying efforts against sex work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: They also explicitly distance themselves from self-identified sex workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: who they often accuse of being nothing but criminals
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Using the stigma of sex work
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: anti-prostitution activists have managed to ally themselves with mostly sexually and socially conservative groups in their call for the suppression of sex work
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: using slogans like"end demand" or "abolish prostitution now", they have been calling for the so-called "Swedish Model", in which the act of selling sex is formally decriminalised, while clients are charged with a monetary fine
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: By increasing the cost of a sexual transaction, the law should work as a deterrent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A variation of the law has been implemented in other small countries, such as Norway, Iceland, and, most recently, Northern Ireland
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Supporters of this approach claim that only this particular law will reduce human trafficking as well as prostitution
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: However
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Swedish approach comes with many flaws and open questions
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Because its goal is a society without sex workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the law does not intend to provide any guidance on the laws we need in a society with sex workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Norway is considering repealing the law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the evaluation of the law has not been able to prove its success
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: While
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the EUROSTAT report on human trafficking does not point to a decrease in human trafficking in Sweden
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: sex workers' working conditions have worsened
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the "Swedish Approach" criminalises any attempt to create safe working environments for sex workers
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: anyone renting indoor space to sex workers can be charged with "pimping"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Ironically, this provision has not reduced pimping, but induced many landlords to put sex workers on the streets in order to avoid a fine for "pimping", as the so-called "Operation homeless" has shown in Norway
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Furthermore
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Sweden does not allow immigration for the purposes of prostitution and has been deporting migrant sex workers
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: who are still seen a problem of public order and security
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: It wasn't until 2011 that a Swedish Court ruled that deporting citizens of the European Union selling sex in Sweden was illegal
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Last but not least, even Sweden and Norway tax income from sex work, while refusing to recognise it as labour
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: As empirical studies on the implementation of the "Swedish approach" show, its weaknesses in guaranteeing sex workers' human rights, policy-makers also have become sceptical
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A Special Committee of French Senate excluded the provision criminalising clients from the proposed new prostitution law in summer 2014 - based on the recommendations of the National Consultative Commission on Human Rights
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: So far, it is unclear whether France will go forward with the law at all
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Britain has also excluded the provision criminalising the purchase of sex from its "Modern Slavery Bill"
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: which has itself been criticised by NGOs for not doing justice to victims of human trafficking
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Germany is also working to reform its prostitution law
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The Global Network of Sex Work Projects advocates "decriminalisation" of sex work
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: So far
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: only New Zealand has chosen "decriminalisation" as sex work policy
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: but
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: maybe India will be next
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: India's chair of the National Commission of Women, Lalitha Kumaramangalam, recently stated that the "Immoral Traffic Prevention Act" should be revised in order to create"conditions conductive for sex workers to live with dignity"
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: In fact
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the existing law casts sex workers simultaneously as dangerous to society and as victims to be forcefully protected from their own choices
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Either way, they are not recognised as equal citizens, workers, and members of a social and political community with human rights
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: By decriminalising sex work, India would set an example for other countries, too
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: As
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: a law practitioner recently pointed out that "the position of defining prostitution itself as inherently exploitative and a form of violence against women does not allow people in prostitution to access their right to earn a livelihood through sex work."
paragraphs.label: testimony

paragraphs.text: It is time for democracies to include sex workers in policy-making processes and take them seriously - not just because democratic values mandate it, but because sex workers are the experts on the matter
paragraphs.label: assumption
